Like others have said, I've fed the local magpies and turned them into friends. I have no idea if it helped to charm them, but I also would whistle the same tune to them when I saw them. It wasn't the same tune they sing, but in a similar style. My best magpie story is that one time when hanging out washing, I had a couple parent magpies along with their juveniles hoping around the grass near me, picking bugs out of our lawn. Suddenly I heard the call of a swooping magpie (you learn this pretty quick when you live around them). Myagpie buddies began squawking at the newcomer and the swooping magpie abandoned their dive and sat on a nearby tree branch instead. I like to think that my friendly magpies were telling the aggressor that I'm chill and feed them. I've never come across any other anecdotes or research similar to this, but I thought this would be a good way to share.

I still whistle to magpies whenever I see magpies but have moved from the place I was living when I used to feed them. When I whistle, all magpies seem to cock their heads and look at me (cocking heads is done my many animals to help pinpoint the location of sounds). I don't think the whistling alone would be enough to befriend magpies, but I think maybe the "attempt" at conversation helps to break the ice.

I believe feeding magpies at any point, not just during breeding seasons will help you get off on the right foot with them, but haven't done enough experiments to confirm.

In truth I've never been hurt by magpies although I've been swooped plently of times. I have, however, had my earlobe cut by a swooping butcherbird as a child. Butcherbirds are a close relative of magpies.

Along with the porcupine (or ecidhna) helmet, you can put eye stickers or paint them on the back of your helmet. OK, my third and last comment: Seriously, you rarely worry about any of these animals/plants while you're in Australia. You kind of have to go looking for trouble. I've lived in Sydney for 40 years now and only seen a real life Funnel Web in a jar -  it was one that a friend had caught. Magpies are smart and cool animals that MIGHT hassle you for a week or two, if you're unlucky. Ticks are more a worry for your pets. Deaths from any of these means are super rare. Australian doctors are experts with anti-venom and our hospitals are solid. So, this is why Australians love videos and articles about how 'hardcore' it is here... because it's not really dangerous, but it makes us look like badasses.

At school in Frenchs Forest NSW, we used to have a clearing in the bushes we called 'The Ticks'. It was behind the teacher's carpark. We'd go down there at lunch and smoke cones a lot. Why was it called The Ticks? Yep. So the next class, we'd be stoned and pulling ticks out of our arms, brushing off our clothes. Leaving them on the desks.
Side story... we started to grow out of The Ticks eventually - so some Year 9s start going down there to claim the turf. Teachers called the cops and had them arrested at school. Turns out the teachers knew what my group was up to, but let it slide because we were older and already reprobates. Those teachers were cool. Well, it's either that, or we were good at sneaking down there unnoticed, while the year 9s were clowns. Either way.

Poor magpies. I love them, but I have been attacked before and the torment is not to be underestimated. I'm walking down the street and suddenly it was like someone whacked the crown of my head with a spiked hammer. Super violent, hammer blow stuff and I'm actually seeing stars. I work out what's going on and stop. The bird lands in front of me and just stares me down, Hitchcock style. I move to the left, it moves to the left. I walk a step forward, it stands ground. I get into denial mode and walk 'confidently' forward to the right. The bird flies up, circles and eff's me up again. I stop. The bird land in front of me. Stares me down.... repeat. Hassle. But the experience just made me respect them more.

Why don't we put this into perspective? I am sure you could make a similar film about the USA or any other country for that matter.
Magpies: They will swoop in the nesting season but the birds are intelligent and recognise people. I never get swooped because I interact with the magpies in my area during the year and they know and trust me. Befriend the magpies and you won't get swooped - and they are entertaining friends.
Paralysis ticks: The most common victims of these are dogs but you can get a pill that prevents dogs getting ticks and fleas. Ticks will bite humans but they can be found and removed. Most people are never in an area where they are likely to come in contact with them. By the way, "cheese fries" and the "Outback steakhouse" are American, not Australian and have nothing to do with Australia.
Centipedes: There are big centipedes and they are usually found in wooded areas away from cities. Most people have never seen one.
Strychnine Tree: About a thousand species of trees, flowers and shrubs in Australia are poisonous. Don't eat stuff unless you know what it is, is the basic rule. People follow the same rule worldwide with mushrooms. It isn't difficult. The Strychnine Tree grows along the east coast from northern NSW into Queensland. Most Australians never come across it.
Cone Shells: Don't pick them up, it's simple. That goes for the tiny blue-ringed octopus too. Leave them alone.
Gympie-Gympie Tree. Australia is the same size as the USA (without Alaska) and you warn everyone about one tree that grows in one out-of-the-way rainforest up in far northeast Queensland. Most Australians and visitors will never go anywhere near it. If they do, they would be warned.
Irukandji jellyfish: Yes they are in the tropical waters of the far north coast. So are saltwater crocodiles, box jellyfish, venomous sea snakes and sharks. People do not swim off beaches in the north in the wet season. In the dry season the jellyfish have gone. Snorkelling and diving on reefs off the coast is relatively safe as the jellyfish are near the coast.

Magpies are lovely birds, their call is so beautiful and waking up in the early hours of the morning to hear them is a pleasure,

Sure they are territorial, but they are also highly intelligent. You can bribe them with food and you will have a friend for life due to their good memories. Also they tell each other who is a problem and who is helpful. What find remarkable is that when I go for a walk and they are foraging, if I look at them they will take off when I'm 30-50m away but if I look elsewhere as I walk past them I can pass within 2-3 metres of them.

I've sat and had lunch within metres of the tree which they were nesting in without issue.

I think they are smarter than crows.

I think it's a fact that bikes allow you to approach so fast and quietly like a predator that spooks them, riding more slowly and ringing your bell occasionally will probably prevent a lot of issues, and because they recognise and remember faces feeding etc improves rapport.

Much more of a problem are spur winged plovers, they breed on the ground in large grassy areas and when walking you here a banshee like sound. As you get closer to the nest they get louder and louder until they decide enough is enough and they start swooping until you are well and truly gone. Feeding etc. doesn't help, it's simply get out of Dodge. Maybe they don't get a mention because they are so vocal prior to attack.

I have spent most of my 60+ years of life on Australia's east coast, where these things are found evidently. Some on this list I've never heard of, and most I've never interacted with.

Maggies, sure. We have a (very noisy) family of them in our street. I find if you leave them alone, they mostly leave you alone. Every injury I've heard of from magpies was somewhat self-inflicted by people trying to avoid their swoops.

I have seen a Gympie Gympie, but was pre-warned by locals to go nowhere near it.

Since childhood, I was taught to always wear something like hard sandals when swimming anywhere near a coral reef, because of the Cone Snails (and Stonefish).

I have heard of the Common Kingslayer (although we always used the more general term "Irukandji" or the even more general "Box Jellyfish"). As an adult, when swimming in the tropics, I have tended to wear a stinger suit to protect against these and other nasties (like Blue-Ringed Octopus and Bluebottle).

We do have good public health infrastructure in Australia so that, in the unlikely event that you do have an unpleasant interaction with any on this list, you will be well cared for.

Australia is notorious for its wildly toxic or ferocious animals, but the dangerous wildlife in Australia has similarly dangerous counterparts outside of Australia.  For example, the funnel web spider's counterpart is probably the wandering spider of Latin America, and the inland taipan is comparable to mambas of Africa (mambas are deadlier because they're more aggressive and live near people, but taipans have a more potent venom).  Where Australia has big powerful crocodiles, Africa has big powerful hippopotami, and the gympie gympie is probably not much more dangerous than the manchineel of Florida.  Either way, that's a lot of dangerous wildlife concentrated on one island, so I think I'll stick to visiting Europe or China lol

Magpies are, indeed, very smart and very social. They also have demonstrable facial recognition. I made friends with my local magpie family by rescuing one of their chicks from the dogs in my back yard. I had to get the dogs to go to their beds, then went out with gloves on and a pair of shorts to find the wounded chick, threw the shorts over him (the little fella's pop was watching me the whole time, and shrieked at me when I threw the shorts, looked like he wanted to attack, but I was moving slow and as unaggressively as I could think of, and he didn't attack me). I then scooped him up still covered by the shorts, and he was pretty calm, then popped him over the fence to the front yard, where he reunited with his parents. He couldn't fly for a few hours, but that afternoon, they'd all buggered off. They used to swoop me on my walks through a local park all the time through spring. Now, they just let me walk on by, and even hop up to me from time to time to see if I have anything for them. Every now and again, I might have a little left over kabana from the local store that I'll share with them. They know who I am, and I know who they are. I might even almost call them friends of mine.


That being said, yes, magpies know that humans, specifically, are a threat. You might see them swooping people one minute, and the next, ignoring the random kangaroo grazing nearby completely. And they definitely remember you. If you strike at them when they're swooping, chances are, they'll become even more aggressive towards you the next time they see you.

I love these types of videos... Yes, there are dangerous animals here. You have to be REALLY unlucky to meet the worst and really stupid to get bitten, stung or anything else ( or you have an accidental encounter but any animal will try to protect itself). Most Aussies just go about their business like anyone else in other countries. It only seems horrible and scary if it isn't the norm...
Rule of thumb, if it slithers on the ground , stand still and wait for it to move away, jumping around well prompt an attack, so will trying to kill it. Spiders are all around and most won't bite unless it is a matter of you trying to hurt them or by the spider mistaking you for prey (red backs won't chase you and will try to get away of they aren't protecting they eggs). Most aren't poisonous even if they do bite. If in catching, safely catch the spider, don't kill, in a container for identification if unsure and sell medical advice.
Don't go swimming when the boards are out warning of jellyfish season, during Box jellyfish season a FULL BODY wetsuit is best if you MUST go in the water but the smaller irukandji jellyfish can be swallowed by accident.
As for the magpies, you leave them alone, feed them and soon that learned behavior works to your advantage as they recognise you as a food source and not a threat... Did this at work and the work crews working in my area found out quite quickly that this works brilliantly. Never had anyone since complain of being swooped though it was a problem before I arrived.

One night in 1942 during training in Northern Queensland before he shipped off to Milne Bay in New Guinea, my old man decided that staying awake all night to defend their position against an inevitable attack by the "enemy" wasn't for him.
He and the other blokes with him carefully cut branches off nearby Gympie bushes and laid them out on the ground, completely surrounding their position.
They all then went to sleep.

Awoken a while later by shrieking from all directions, they "killed" the bad guys in seconds.
For that, my Dad was promoted to Sergeant and also copped 48 hours confined to barracks, because he'd sent 15 Aussie soldiers to hospital.
Resourceful bugger he was.

in high school, during magpie season, there were about 5 different magpie nests on our school oval (or “field” for you Americans). Almost half the school (300-400 children) had to walk through or past the nests every afternoon. It was terrifying. You’d have groups of 5 children banding together, no matter if they knew each other or not, and run in a scattered pattern to try and disorient the magpies. Sometimes kids would get swooped and get cuts from their beaks, other times kids would get swooped and they would swing their backpacks wildly to try and hit the bird before the bird hit them. It’s funny to watch if you’re the one not being swooped but if you’re the one being swooped, it’s like WW3 has started.

Australia may seem like a dangerous place, but the biggest land predators we have are literally medium dog sized dingoes, and crocs in the far north. In places like north America you have pumas, bears and moose. In Africa you have rhinos, hippos, elephants and other gargantuan beasts you stand no chance against. In Europe you also have bears, wolves, moose and the like. With venomous animals like the majority of feared Australian wildlife, there are antivenoms and ways to prevent injuries even if you get attacked. For example, the extremely venomous Australian snakes you hear about have very small fangs. By wearing thick pants and boots you can almost guarantee your safety, even if you are bitten. But with large territorial animals that want to trample and maul you, there isn’t exactly an antidote for internal bleeding or broken bones. You can outrun a spider or a snake, but you can’t outrun a territorial lion or bear.

Thanks for your funny (albeit alarmist) video, but update your facts, please. Where DO you get your information from? Obviously NOT from any reliable source(s), as almost all Australians who watched this video would know. Here are (but a few) examples:
1. Magpies can be found in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia...and not just on the coast. You (somehow) omitted at least 3 States, equal in size to over 1/4 of the U.S.
2. Most magpies in the southern Sates are about 40cm in size, but are generally larger in north eastern States.
3. The 3,200 magpie attacks and 520 injuries in 2017 alone were those requiring enough medical aid to be reported. The real number of attacks by magpies (who don't just seek out cyclists, but MAINLY pedestrian foot traffic) would easily be far in excess of 100,000. We don't like it, but (as Australians) we know it happens and take steps to avoid, and we don't make a "big song and dance" over it. Wrong country for that.
4. The most common and effective magpie deterrent adaption to helmets (and/or hats) is to paint or draw eyes on the back, not spikes around and over it.
5. Paralysis ticks and issues from them in Australia are exceedingly rare, so much so (if any did occur), they'd make the nightly news...and they generally don't.
6. Outback Steakhouse aka Outback Jacks (and it's delicious American cheese fries) is NOT Australian in both concept or ownership, but an American company, originating in Canada. We have a few (but comparatively not many) here, and it would be one of the smaller chains of (American) food places.
7. The 16cm centipede is NOT found "pretty much everywhere in Australia". Much smaller ones however are...and yes, their bite hurts.
8. Strychnine trees are real but exceedingly rare and sparse. So much so, you'd have to go searching for a long time (days, weeks or months) in most places to find one.

Fun stories from the three-ish days I spent in Australia: Warning for a bit of long read because I just took my ADHD meds :)
Background info:
-I was (and still am) really paranoid about venomous or poisonous creatures. I'm talking I walked around with big "world's deadliest creatures" books. I made maps of where these things lived. I gave my mom a list when we were on the plan of all the dangerous animals in Australia complete with how to recognize them.
-We spent they day we landed in Melbourne, and slept with work friends of my mom that night. Then spent the morning and afternoon of the second day there before flying to Sydney that evening, and spent the third day exploring and sightseeing. I said three-ish because we went to Bondai the morning of the fourth day and went straight from there to the airport


1: Had a spider (Hunstman) crawl up my leg and do the whole "legs up im gonna bite you" thing. I was alone in the room, so I was pretty much doomed. Until our friends' dog, Poppy (a pitbull mix, and the sweetest dog you will ever meet)
2: Found a paralysis tick on my leggings
2: Saw a cone snail kill a crab (it was like...fingernail sized but still)
3: Barely managed to stop my sister and her new friend from picking up said cone snail (I was like 7, they were both 3 years older and my sister thought I wanted to keep the shell for myself because we usually had "pretty shell" competitions and we're both complete goblins when it comes to pretty things). If an old lady hadn't been passing by and recognized it, one of them would have definitely picked it up.
4: Met a lady in the blue mountains walking her service dog, his name was Legolas (best name for a dog if you ask me), a weekend tradition of theirs. Pretty normal right? Yeah except doggo was covered head to toe in what was basically a raincoat body suit, dog goggles and weird half muzzle thing that covered the top of his snout. Apparently three years prior she had a seizure (what he was there for) and Legolas in his search for help had run straight through a gympie gympie bush.

This list is definitelly lacking the one single worst specie of Australia: The Giant Bull Ant. It is in fact the guiness book record holder for the most dangerous ant in the world. But what makes it so special you ask? Well...
The damn thing is a 5cm long ant, so about the size of your pinky, somehow trapped in a sort of suspended state of evolution, with a reusable stinger on it's back just like wasps have, except that this one carries one of the most potent substance in the insect world. On top of that, unlike, all other ants, these bad boys have propper vision, big wide eyes allowing them to see clearly as far as two meters away.
Now what got them their name of bull-ants is not their size, nor their hellish mandibules, it is their aggressivity. They will pick a fight with anything that they see move using their sharp eyesight, be it a bettle, a cat, a python, or a 2m tall human, regardless of any sort of self-preservation instinct. Hand-sized Wolf and huntsmen spiders won't even fight back if they end up cornered by one of them, they will just try to run even if there's no way out. And they are wise to do so, there's not a chance that their mandibules will manage to pierce a bull ant's heavily reinforced skelleton, which can withstand the weight of a human adult standing on it .
As for their sting, well, i know quite a bit about it myself. It's about as painfull as i picture giving birth would be, i'd define it as someone ripping open your flesh and hammering on a nerv with a chisel. Though thankfully the worst of the pain stops under half an hour. It can provoke a choc sufficient to make you throw up if you got stung multiple times, and will attack your flesh, leaving a bruise-like pattern for months. It will also itch pretty badly for weeks.

On top of all of that, remember their suspended state of evolution? These ants don't even need a queen. They have one, but can reproduce between workers and sustain their colony for years without her.

They have a smaller cousin too, refered to as bull ants as well, but also as "jack jumpers". While the stinger of these nasty things pack less of a punch than the one of it's bigger cousin, they trade their weight for the ability to leap in split-second onto other objects, and humans .

Now if you haven't been horrified by this, i suggest that you look what these ants look like on a quick google search.

Tips for survival:
Feed the magpies once, wearing what you wear cycling. They rarely attack again.

Centipedes aren't found everywhere. Only places where it rains, and often only actually in soil or leaf litter. So, only within maybe 6 hours of the eastern and southern coast. They run away very quickly, and I've never heard of anyone getting bitten.

You do come across taipans. Just saying. They just run away, like most snakes. Also, all aussie snakes have both poor eyesight, and small fangs. They can't bite through shoes or jeans, and they struggle to see still things, so if you are really worried just stop moving for a couple of minutes, and it will likely slither away.

Stay on designated walking paths in the forest, or wear long clothes. Or both. Then no problem plants, and no ticks. No leeches and fewer mozzie bites too. Also, then you won't be a missing person statistic.
Many adventurous tourists and even locals just end up missing on their walks. Most of the time they're found, but not all the time.

The kinglayer is not called that here, at least not by most people. People just call them irukandji, which is the type of jelly they are, or just stingers or jellies. All you do is buy and wear a stinger suit and you are gold. Or just avoid swimming in stinger areas.

When you get bored on a train and decide to write some Australian Gothic...

You walk across the street and enter the park, the sun is warm but somehow you are unsettled. People walk past you, their footsteps hurried and their eyes nervous. They walk with heads down but eyes up, a strange combination. The atmosphere should be relaxed yet a nervous tension is shrouding the greenery like thick fog. You start to hurry, eager to reach the safety of the concrete jungle across the park. Something darts across your perifwral vision, gone before you could see it properly. You speed up, walking faster now, almost running. The wind in the trees is a sinister whisper, like a warning. Suddenly it attacks, seemingly from nowhere. A flash of feathers, black and white, sharp beak, beady eyes. It sings a hauntingly beautiful song before diving towards you once more. You break into a run, hands over your head as others around you scatter. You see the edge of the park as you hear the impossibly loud flap of wings that veer away at the last second. Your feet hit concrete and you keep running... It is, after all, magpie season.

Do you want to know another way to deal with magpie attacks? Shotguns. Shotguns work really well. The same magpie that learned to attack humans can also learn that attacking humans leads to being blasted into little more than a cloud of red mist and destroyed feathers.

Seriously, these animals have learned that humans no longer represent a real threat to them and therefore it is safe to attack them. Fortunately with magpies it's not really something that you really have to worry about too much, but there is another Australian animal that has also learned this lesson, and they kill people on a regular basis: the Indo-Pacific crocodile, a.k.a. the saltwater crocodile or the Salty. Since being granted protected status back in the 70's their numbers have exploded to levels never seen before, and they have lost all their fear of humans. In fact, they're one of the few animal species on Earth that actively hunt humans. So, if you're planning a trip to Northern Australia, stay away from the water!

Paralysis ticks don't leap. They stand on plants and grab onto passing mammals that brush against them. If you need to go into an area where you're likely to come across them, use a tropical strength insect repellent, cover up in light-coloured clothing (so you can see any crawling on you), and change clothes as soon as you can.

Questions to ask yourself when determining the danger of a species:
1. Will it kill you? (If yes, it's bad. If not, less bad). If so how fast? (If it's less than about 30 min, you might be in trouble). Is there an antivenom or treatment? (If not, you might be in trouble. If yes, it's less bad).
2. If it doesn't kill you, how bad is the pain? (If you need hospital treatment, it's bad. If not, have some ice or stingoes!) How long does the pain last? (more than a day, it's bad) Is there treatment for it? (if ice, stingoes or panadol don't work, you might need help)

Magpies are freaking awesome! They are incredibly intelligent and have no problems remembering faces. They remember and will swoop people who have tormented them in the past, but if they recognize a friendly face will follow them, bring their babies for almost a meet and greet and leave you alone. I have several that follow me (running on the ground, they spend a fair amount of time on the ground) when gardening and will wait outside my front door. They even come from half a block away when I tap the bird feeder. They will often be in pairs and raise their young as a family, with both parents taking turns to find food. If they like you, they will bring their babies out to meet you, and eat from your hand. Amazing birdies!

I'm dismayed to see you adding to the media frenzy against magpies. This kind of coverage feeds the fear/aggression spiral that magpies face now. Gone are the days when you wore a hat and coped with swooping season because nature's cycles were part of life. Now, increased aggression from humans leads to more swooping which can lead to the magpie being caught and removed which leaves the female to raise the chicks on her own (only the males swoop) which leads to increased chick mortality.  Thanks for a great channel, just saddened to see the magpie focus in this video.

I see a lot of comments by people saying how scary Australia is but Hank was right to point out that horses kill the most people in Australia. Horses killed 74 people between 2000 and 2013, followed by bees and snakes 27 each (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-38592390). Meanwhile spiders killed nobody during this time. So you will probably be fine if you go to Australia, as long as you don't go horse riding, have an allergy to bees or go for a walk in long grass in a place with no mobile reception. The only other animals that kill anyone is sharks and crocs' but crocs' mainly kill locals who don't believe signs that say things like "Don't swim here" or "Caution, no fishing here" and even have pictures of croc's for people who can't speak English. Meanwhile sharks usually kill one or two people a year, so you really have to be unlucky to eaten by one.

inhales, time for a good old Aussie hello
Magpies: Befriending can be good but in minimal amounts, befriend to avoid swooping not befriend to have a pet, they are wild animals. Signs are casually put up warning people of swooping zones. If you do get attacked and can't leave the area walk backwards and stare up (they know your looking and don't like it) or grab a leafy branch and hold it over your head, eye stickers on hats don't really work. You never hear them coming, sometimes you'll see a shadow but when close they can make a weird 'click click' sound with their wings. If you hear that either get away or find a tree branch to put over your head. Don't run... seriously it just angers them more. It was one guy that had his eye taken out, even then it sounds like a far fetched rumor. Yeah they can get ya but it's mostly scratches or shallow cuts to the head.
Para Trick: I am Aussie and NEVER heard of this meat allergy and I've had multiple para ticks during my years. Sure they make you feel like utter hell and sometimes antibiotics are needed but never heard of someone becoming allergic to meat, if you do go into the scrub, wear long sleeves and when out check EVERYWHERE for ticks, even behind your ears. You might be thinking of the Lone Star tick and that's in the US. Also Outback Steakhouse is NOT Aussie angry shook noises
Strychnine Tree: Yeah no one eats random fruit off trees. Hell trying to get an Aussie to eat any fruit is tricky xD
Good old cone snail shells!: HAHAHA yeah they are nasty, old gold rule: if it's in the water leave it be. Also wear solid soled water shoes.
Gympie Gympie tree: STAY. ON. THE. PATHS. WHEN. NATURE. WALKING. AND. PAY. ATTENTION. TO. SIGNS! Seriously, please it's dangerous also take photos! Beautiful scenery up top!
Common KingSlayer: I REPEAT THE NATURE WALK WARNING! Keep an eye out for signs on beaches, DO YOUR RESEARCH! It's a quick 5 minute google, dont be an idiot or 'tough' mother nature does not care. Stay between the flags or out of the water if it's not a dedicated area or a local swimming hole and if you're completely unsure, just go into a local store or find a life guard and ask. We wont bite, but we can keep you from getting hurt and STAY BETWEEN THE RED AND YELLOW FLAGS! HOW MANY TIMES MUST WE REPEAT THIS! <3

What won't kill you there

1: If in magpie season, in a known swooping area, keep something above your head, they will go for the highest point, an umbrella is usually good.
Also yes they are incredibly smart, one time I defended myself with a handbag, actually managed to knock it down without severely injuring it, it got up, flew away and never bothered me again, although it did still bother other people.

2: Already eating mostly vegan, so no problem mate, also the amount of people going vegetarian or vegan in Australia is rapidly increasing, even without this tic induced allergy.

3: If you saw one you'd keep away from it too, 'big bug don't touch' is basic logic to most people, unless you're and entomologist, in which case you'd probably already have studied the animal in question.

4: If you're not 100% certain don't eat it is a pretty simple concept, if you can apply it to mushrooms why not other plants?

5: Don't go swimming in wild waters alone, and if in doubt wear a wet suit, preferably one that is thick and brightly coloured. don't touch stuff unless you know for certain what it is.

6: If You want to avoid most of the worst stuff, stay to the southern parts of Australia.

7: see number 5 and 6

As an Aussie zoologist, i can confirm:

1) Magpies are dicks, most people have been swooped.
2) Paralysis ticks are not fun. Ive had one on my neck, and know many pets who have died from them.
3) I had one of these bastards scratching around near my head in my tent 2 weeks ago, cenitipede venom is quite nasty.
4) No experience with this plant, but it doesnt surprise me. Many of the plants here are quite toxic.
5) Cone snails are hard to treat and quite lethal. Populations on different reefs can have different chemical concoctions in their venom, making antivenoms nearly impossible.
6) Stinging trees suck. Ive had it on the soft skin on the underside of my arm, and without immediate waxing of the needles it will persist for months.
7) Irukandji as we call them is probably the worst pain known to man. My professor in toxinology had been stung 11 times, search for jamie seymour - irukandji and watch his experience in hospital.
